intro: Prunus avium proles sylvestris, commonly known as the wild cherry tree, is a species native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, featuring a rounded crown and smooth, gray bark. The plant produces showy white or pink flowers in the spring, which are followed by sweet, edible cherries in the summer. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a serrated margin, contributing to its ornamental value. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands and open areas.
